results.title: Mitosis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology Program. Unit 5. Heredity and Adaptive Change”.
Shows a mitosis actually taking place in a living cell. Demonstrates the effects of chemicals and radiation on dividing cells. Discusses the importance of mitosis to the growth and maintenance of an organism. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Kiwis
results.creator_credit: Paul Williams, John Sparkes, Janet Bell and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Ernie Leonard, a Maori who had relinquished his traditions and heritage became chief of his tribe at the age of 55. He had been a television compere, later becoming a television producer and Ernie was able to show how he had learnt language and traditions and helped in fostering this knowledge in the young. He now produces a television program in Maori each week called ‘Koha’.

results.title: Meiosis: sex cell formation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology Program. Unit 5. Heredity and Adaptive Change”.
This film explains how meiosis, or reduction division occurs in the formation of sex cells. It illustrates the sequence of changes in the parent-cell nucleus which results in the creating of two daughter cells, each having half as many chromosomes as the parent cell. Meiosis also enables plants and animals to produce offspring with a variety of characteristics.

results.title: Dingo country
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
A fence almost 6,000 miles long stretches from South Australia to Queensland and attempts to separate the dingo from the sheep. The dingoes are vigorously hunted and killed, but the film presents the view that man must learn to acept the dingo.

results.title: Laws of heredity
results.creator_credit: David Bennett and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology Program. Unit 5. Heredity and Adaptive Change”.
Shows how inheritance is determined in statistically predictable ways. Presents the insights and conclusions about inheritance that were first discovered by Gregor Mendel. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Brush with royalty
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
A group of artists from Broken Hill prepare for an exhibition of their work in London. Artists include Pro Hart and Jack Absalom, and all use the countryside around Broken Hill as their source of inspiration. This film is recommended for students in Years 9-12.

results.title: Gene action
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology Program. Unit 5. Heredity and Adaptive Change”.
Portrays the biochemical mechanisms of inheritance. Shows how the DNA of chromosomes can replicate itself during mitosis and how it can serve as a pattern for the “messenger” DNA. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: A Big Country: The Legend of Jimmy Governor
results.brief_description:
Episode of ABC TV series ‘A Big Country’ exploring the real life story of Jimmy Governor, as compared to his fictional counterpart, Jimmie Blacksmith, in the novel and film, ‘The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith’. Includes interviews with author, Thomas Keneally, and film director, Fred Schepisi, on location during the making of the film.
Broadcast on ABC TV in April 1978. Reporter: Kenyon Castle. Narrator: Bob Plasto.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Shot in Queensland, this film examines the development in styles of houses in Australia, from the slab hut to the contemporary brick house. Suitable for Upper Secondary-Tertiary level students.

results.title: Every little drop: the story of the Snowy Scheme
results.creator_credit: Bruce Belsham, Unapix Entertainment Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big picture”.
In October 1999, a picnic was held at Lake Jindabyne to celebrate 50 years since the Snowy Mountain Scheme first began. The day brought together the workers who survived the huge project, their families and their friends. This program looks at the history of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme, both as an engineering wonder (recognised in 1969 by the American Society of Civil Engineers as one of the seven engineering marvels of the world) and an epic human saga. It took 25 years to build and employed 100,000 workers from around the world, particularly refugees from war-torn Europe. However it also cost 121 lives in the actual construction of the Snowy Scheme and many more on the construction of the roads. Its primary aim was to collect and channel water inland for irrigation, passing through a series of power stations and generating hydro-electricity whose sale would help finance the project. Today questions are being raised about the ecological damage in relation to salinity and excessive use of water for irrigation. Contains interviews with engineers, surveyors and workers from the Snowy Scheme and includes archival news footage and graphical film of the constructions of tunnels, dams and power stations. Narrated by John Gaden.
results.title_for_label: Every little drop: the story of the Snowy Scheme
